Understate: The claim may understate the frequency of filibusters against Supreme Court justices by stating that it has "never really been successfully used," when there is evidence of at least one example in history.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it only provides one example from history, and more research may be needed to determine the frequency and success of filibusters against Supreme Court justices.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may have an alternative explanation as it is possible that the opposition to Fortas' nomination was not a true filibuster, but rather described as such in news accounts at the time.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there has been at least one example of a filibuster against a Supreme Court justice, as evidenced by the opposition to Fortas' nomination.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption that the lack of successful filibusters against Supreme Court justices means they have never been used effectively.
